awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Uncovering the Role of Germline-Specific MAGE-B2 Protein in Maintenance of Cellular Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Fisk University will provide an outstanding venue for students to gain both competence and confidence across more traditional disciplinary lines. The research proposed broadens collaborative research opportunities with other Fisk Faculty, by bringing the tools of mammalian cell culture, epigenetics and computational analyses of gene expression.  

The goal of this project is to determine the fundamental biological processes that drive expression (transcription) of MAGE-B2, a member of this enigmatic gene family, and test the hypothesis that aberrant expression of MAGE-B2 perturbs cell cycle control, proliferation and/or differentiation. Melanoma antigen genes (MAGEs) encode for proteins that are critical regulators of endosomal trafficking, neuronal development, cell cycle progression and germ cell development.  A subset of the MAGE proteins (Type I MAGEs) is physiologically restricted in expression to male germline cells. Aberrant expression in any other cells leads to a wide-variety of cellular dysfunctions pertaining to cell proliferation.  The work involves molecular and cell biological approaches as well as computational analyses critical for engaging in contemporary biological research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on studying the human protein Melanoma Antigen Gene (MAGE)-B2 which is know to be important in cellular development. We used an interdisciplinary approach combining both computational and experimental techniques to understand the role MAGE-B2 plays in maintaining cellular identity. Bioinformatics analysis of publicly available databased revealed stark patterns in DNA modification (methylation) when comparing tissues with high versus low expression of MAGE-B2, suggesting the importance of epigenetic regulation. We were able to confirm this experimentally by inhibiting methylation in a cell line and observing a correlated decrease in MAGE-B2 expression. We also observed a similar trend when looking at acetylation modifications of DNA. Additionally, we identified JunD as the likely transcription factor that regulates MAGE-B2 expression. We were also able to express MAGE-B2 in normal cells and observed that increased expression of MAGE-B2 correlates with increased cell proliferation.  The structure of MAGE-B2 comprises a MAGE homology domain and an intrinsically disordered domain as determined by computational modeling. We hypothesized that the intrinsically disordered domain may play a role in protein-protein interactions. We were able to observe 20 proteins that had correlated transcription levels with MAGE-B2 and co-localized with MAGE-B2 in pull down assays. In total our results provide new insights into MAGE-B2 function and serve as a foundation for exploring the detailed molecular mechanism of MAGE-B2 induced cellular proliferation. The results from this project were presented at 12 conferences (both regional and national) and 3 peer reviewed manuscripts were published. In addition to the scientific outcomes of our studies, the project had several important educational accomplishments as well. A total of 4 master’s degrees were awarded and 11 undergraduate students participated in academic year or summer research experiences. All of the students are currently working in STEM related fields or pursuing STEM related advanced degrees. 

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2025
Modified by: Steven Damo
